title: Since her rework, Sona has seen 0 competitive play
body:
Not to say that her competitive scene was bustling before the rework, but she was played a few times at each event
But since the rework we see nothing of her, and why would any high tier player pick her? she requires a ton of AP to be decent, all while being easily killable at all points in the game

People may feel that she shouldn't be in a position to considered a competitive pick, even rarely, because she is a easy champion
But it's not exactly fair when Lee Sin gets buffs because "lower tier plays don't do well with him" while there are champions like Sona who sit on their hands and forcing people to play better supports with a higher skillcap like the 2 champions who have made her irrelevant (Naut and Nami, who lest i remind you is getting buffed and annoyingly in the area Sona needs it)

If Lee gets buffs out of nowhere for the excuse that lower elo players don't do well with them, what about champions that higher elo players don't do well with and consider a handicap for being played as they limit your skill

replies.body: Why do you think teams occasionally picked her before, but no longer do? Is it strictly that she's been too nerfed? That she's not standing out as far as what she brings to the table? That she's being crowded out by other supports? Or something else?

> [{quoted}](name=RiotRepertoir,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=l4fPAZ8v,comment-id=000a,timestamp=2015-08-14T15:58:34.113+0000)
>
> Why do you think teams occasionally picked her before, but no longer do? Is it strictly that she's been too nerfed? That she's not standing out as far as what she brings to the table? That she's being crowded out by other supports? Or something else?

I think it's because in the past she didn't need gold to function at all. Her auras were just base stats, they didn't need to scale off of anything. But now she scales off of AP in absolutely everything and her base values are frankly quite poor. Her poke in particular is pretty much balanced around her picking up a Sheen at this point, which quite simply isn't going to happen in competitive play.

Also, as another guy said, people are just terrible at playing against her in solo q. People call Sona easy but against a good opponent she's really not, which is the problem with competitive. Playing aggressively with a champion who's made out of paper has a ton of risks associated with it, especially against tanky supports who can genuinely 100-0 her if they land their engage in the early levels. But she's balanced around people not retaliating because solo q players are a lot more likely to run away from Sona's poke than they are to fight her back, even though after she's used her damage is the best possible time to attack her.
This post pretty much sums up Sona's problem.
She has no more auras, she has no more identity. Sona is now a Q poke bot, which is not valuable enough.

This, 100 percent.  The only way for a team to benefit off of a Sona support instead of a walking-CC like every other support (Braum/Morgana/Nami/ect) was her auras.  Now, she has to just cycle and spam all her spells, and the buffs change so rapidly that they don't benefit anyone.  The ONLY way to play her now is as a poke champ, but even that doesn't work since you need to rush a Sheen to do so.  

Her viability in lower ELOs is the fact that nobody wants to take poke, and retreat.  Once you hit higher ELOs or the pro scene, thats no longer an issue.  Therefore, no Pro play.
Relic shield makes sona's poke less valuable, and makes tank supports have comparable sustain.
For free. They heal for free.
No they actually get paid to heal.

Her problem is that she's extremely squishy on top of being COMPLETELY unable to do anything about hard engage pre-6. Leona can pretty much guarantee a kill on her at level one if the ADC is nearby.

The nerfs made little sense, they were said to be because she dominates her winning matchups too hard, but they did nothing to address that while making her losing matchups even worse. She's still horribly oppressive in certain matchups, but the laning phase is now borderline unwinnable at a high level against others.

> [{quoted}](name=RiotRepertoir,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=l4fPAZ8v,comment-id=000a,timestamp=2015-08-14T15:58:34.113+0000)
>
> Why do you think teams occasionally picked her before, but no longer do? Is it strictly that she's been too nerfed? That she's not standing out as far as what she brings to the table? That she's being crowded out by other supports? Or something else?

1) Support/Mage champs ARE being crowded out by other supports...maybe save Morgana. Almost every competitive pick is a tanky engage support. All the support/mage picks or the mage/support picks are either better off mid lane or better off not being played competitively.

2) She IS too nerfed. She doesn't do insane amounts of damage unless she goes mid and builds it, but anyone else can emulate that damage anyway. There's no reason why her Q shouldn't be able to out-damage the sustain of a Doran's Blade at level 1 (I thought A Wild AP Sona was just using hyperbole on this point, but not only did I start winning more after changing my mindset after reading his rage post, he was fking right...). Even then, her utility components are relatively weak in comparison to nearly any other support simply because they're aoe. The problem is that they're too weak. You're not giving enough incentive to prefer shielding 5 people with a short, crappy shield over shielding one person with a shield so damn massive it takes an ult or a crit to shred it off while it lasts for a good 2-3 or so seconds while giving other benefits like movement or damage. The cost on the shield+heal is too high for how weak it is as well.

So part of it is a meta problem that hasn't been addressed for a long time (tank supports are way too valuable and do too much while mage supports can't really excel at damage-dealing because they'll just go mid, but they can't lock people down because they're squishy and easy to punish), and part of it is the fact that you guys over-nerfed Sona in the long run.

It's pretty much the problem that Nami outclasses her in every single regard, not to mention that Thresh is a thing.

I think it all boils down to that Sona just isn't a safe pick with how powerful supports have become. Also, despite this risk, Sona just isn't very rewarding when you do well as her, sure you do a lot more damage than most other supports, but you can't really push a lane or do anything on your own still.

Overall Sona is high risk, low reward, so she never going to be highly sought after. I don't believe there's anything inherently wrong with her, and I love her kit, it's just easy to recognize why I wouldn't want to go into ranked with her.

All of the squishy supports are TOO squishy IMO.  Especially with the high popularity of hard engage supports meaning you're almost guaranteed to lane against one.  Then they'll engage on you and probably kill you instantly.  At that point it doesn't really matter how much poke and utility you have.

But Sona is particularly bad because she's so short ranged now, it's almost impossible to do anything useful while staying safely positioned.  You can't trade when the enemy can 100-0 you.

She is a ranged poke support.  This puts her mostly in competition with Janna, Nami, and Morgana.  Sona used to be the queen of poke supports, and for this, her CC was extremely limited.  She did better damage and healed any poke her opponents put out, but lacked the ability to escape from engages.  Higher damage is always going to be more useful in the early game.  CC matters less because CC largely stays the same throughout the game.   You lock someone down for 2 seconds early, but your teammate doesn't have the damage to kill them in 2 seconds.  You do that later on in the game, and that person gets deleted by your teammate.  

High damage in the early game zones out opponents and forces them to be more aggressive, specifically more predictably aggressive.  When Leona and her ADC come back to lane from base, having been poked out by Sona previously, you KNOW they are going to want to engage quickly if they can, while they have full health and Sona has less mana.  They know if they wait, she's just going to poke them.  If your jungler is there waiting, instead of killing Sona, they get double killed.

Now, however, because she was seen as too much of a bully, she was nerfed, without any compensation in other areas to make up for that.  She STILL lacks the CC and disengage of the more viable ranged poking supports, and she is still just as squishy as she always was.

Her aura effects look "fun" and "interactable" on paper but at the end of the day, it only restricts her movement and independence in lane. You have a perfectly telegraphed Q aura that requires you to be close to your adc so they can do the auto-attack nuke on their adc. If you're laning against a competent post-6 annie or Leona, it's not gonna happen. They'll either kill you or heal through your "skillfully timed poke" with relic shield. 

Post rework Sona is also terrible for new players. When you lane with people new to the game, they are not likely to interact with Leona's or Braum's; they are not certain about the outcome so they don't want to trade/fight. But they can understand "go in when they are low" and they want the 20 ad/ap aura to help them practice CS. Sona heals and provides a movement speed aura so if she sees a gank coming she can escort the adc away, all this independent from her adc. 

With aura ranges so tiny she's not helping much. Getting close to her adc just to keep them out of trouble is asking for Graga and Sejuani ults when they come gank.

Also consider that Karma has group speed boost, an AoE shield, and a Q nuke. Same kit, minus stun but with pre-6 CC.

All of the above and more.

Mind the last part about her ult's mana cost(which took 1 year, 4 months and 2 weeks to fix), I have a list of the majority of her problems right here:

IMO it's a mix of being pushed out, lack of any meaning full identity and overnerfed(which to me is justified because of who she is). 

She got pushed out hard as the main reason to me. She's always had harder time with tankier support. But she would always outscale them since tanky supports didn't have the gold to get as tanky as they needed. Her hardest counters basically became meta. But she's still Sona, and was still strong. But S4 overall pushed her out fairly hard on this alone.

Next up is her lack of identity. Yes she has her aura's, but overall people just keep saying she's a lesser Nami. And you can compare the kits and see that they do a lot of the same things. While I disagree with the statement because they do it in different ways. It still shows there is a problem. You can't have the aura's be strong otherwise it promotes passive play. I think how they function should be rethought. 

Lastly is being overnerfed. Before she has 1-2 ranks in her R she is horrible outside of Q+passiveAA. W will drain her mana. E isn't even taken. Her abilities are trash for a roll that is meant to be stronger early game. 

- Take her aura's, and put them on her passive. Make them meaningful. This would replace the current one. In turn make her base abilities a little more reliable/stronger. To keep Q from being too oppressive you can add a mana-returning mechanic into this new aura setup.
- Using R automatically activates her passive. This gives her kit more depth as she can use it quickly if needed at a cost and allows some combo effects. 
- Using R can also add additional effects. Enemies tagged by an allies Q aura on hit proc will add additional Q strings(making it possible to Q a whole team). W can add an AoE heal, like a weaker version of Janna's ult. E could add a slow field around Sona, one that cannot be dashed into.

Sona's main weakness is initiation. Bot lane is now full of initiators whom Sona simply can't poke down because they are too tanky (she lost a lot of her base power thanks to the combination of the Support scaling utility and her reworked Q "aura" damage, so now requires a lot of AP to actually sunction in pre nerf damage levels).

Partially due to the heavy influence of lane swaps in competitive play and her absolute uselessness outside of a duo lane.  She is made to be a lane bully, which means if there aren't opposing laners to bully, she has nowhere to go.  She doesn't really get anything out of roaming since she doesn't have CC to set up ganks.

Additionally, as a lane bully, she was nerfed quite a bit by the changes to her Q and passive.  It was compensated slightly by increased objective control (Sona comps can do Dragon/Baron really quickly thanks to her Q), but not enough to warrant her other weaknesses.

Sona as a champion is weak to enemy jungle pressure in general. (Can't dickwave Qs freely in lane if enemy jungler is near), and she's one of the least safe champions to attempt to ward on (her E is her only method of self-peel while roaming.  Compare to other meta supports right now like Sona, Alistar, Nautilus, Thresh, etc. who have much stronger methods of ensuring they get out safely.)

As far as her primary niche outside of laning phase, she's an ult bot.  Her auras/spells don't bring team fight impact, only her ult does.  In that regard, Annie far outshines Sona due to her higher burst damage in conjunction with the ult, as well as her additional stuns as a fight gets drawn out.

Her QWE in team fights are really poor overall, with Q's relative short range putting her in too much risk to do anything unless the team fight is drawing to a close (win or lose).



Bullet version:

* Annie is stronger in "FLASH AOE STUN HARD ENGAGE" niche

* QWE unsatisfying outside of laning phase.

* Competitive laning phase usually 1v0 in side lanes, Sona shit roamer.

* Weak to jungle pressure when standard lanes actually happen

Hello.  Sona fan here just wanted to weigh in.  Idk about anyone else, but I asked a few of my diamond and plat friends this and they pretty much all had the same answer:  
1)She's picked for hid dominance in lane and ability to win lane for the adc against most matchups that aren't Leona Thresh and Blitz.
2) Her innate squishiness (is she still the squishiest in the game?) Causes her dominance to be unusable against engage supports or poke supports or adcs unless you coordinate perfectly with your own adc, and even then only certain match-ups work.
3) With all the power given to junglers, ganks are almost inevitably going to be frequent and sona does poorly against any jungler with the ability to engage or any jungler taking advantage of a supports engage.
4) With the popularity of mobility, Sona's e just doesn't make the cut against gap-closing engages or even just running away in general.  Its only really good for chasing people down as a team, and even that is lack luster unless your ahead significantly.  Her and Sivir work well, but if you can't get an advantage, they're less than useless (except for ult).

> [{quoted}](name=RiotRepertoir,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=l4fPAZ8v,comment-id=000a,timestamp=2015-08-14T15:58:34.113+0000)
>
> Why do you think teams occasionally picked her before, but no longer do? Is it strictly that she's been too nerfed? That she's not standing out as far as what she brings to the table? That she's being crowded out by other supports? Or something else?

I think the meta is partly to blame here. Since tanky supports are favored right now, sona isn't a very desirable pick. She's easily all-in'd, and doesn't bring the same utility as other mage supports. When it comes to mage supports, they're all picked for very specific reasons. Karma is picked for her teamwide speed buff. Morg for her black shield. Lulu for her incredible peel and speed boost (even though she's usually put in a solo lane anyway). Janna for the best disengage in the game. Before her nerfs, raka was picked for her unparalleled sustain. Why should a team pick sona, though? She does a little bit of everything, but nothing as well as any of these champions. If a team wants a squishy generalist, they'll probably pick nami, since she has strengths that align more with what teams want (like having hard CC on a basic ability). 

Here's what sona brings to the table:
- Very strong poke
- Some sustain
- Some speed
- An aoe stun ult
-  Every three ability casts: A slow, a damage reduction debuff, or just extra damage

That's her kit in a nutshell. From this profile, her damage seems to be the main reason you should pick her, when damage is one of the last things pros look for in a support. In low elo, kills happen more often, making a support's damage more important; in high elo, utility reigns supreme. Since her strength is damage, that means she is very strong when ahead, capable of bullying enemies out of lane repeatedly, but she doesn't have as much to fall back on when the enemy laners present a significant threat to her. As long as sona follows the profile I outlined above, I don't think it's possible to bring her into a state where she is picked competitively without becoming overbearing for soloqueue. Her identity is simply too at odds with what pros want, meaning she has to be overpowered to be worth picking. 

In light of that, I think these would be the healthiest places to add gameplay:
1) Her E
2) Her powerchord

Simply making her Q more powerful would just make her stronger for soloqueue without really changing anything for the pro scene, and making her sustain better would just promote an uninteractive lane, so making her Q or W stronger is off the table. However, her E is a form of utility that can enable interesting gameplay, giving pros a reason to pick her in the form of a teamwide speed buff, making this probably the healthiest ability to funnel power into. Finding ways to increase the utility on her powerchord (that don't just involve making it do more damage) would be another good direction to take.
Her E should remove slows or something.

VS players who dont know how to handle her, she is overbearing (between bronze and gold)
VS players who do know how to handle her, she is the easiest lane to play against

1. She doesn't have any early cc, it's just her ult and her E auto combo slow.
2. She doesn't have escape so she's easy to pick off early game.
3. She's really really really mana dependant, she's not relevant unless she has clarity or chalice + mana.
4. It's dangerous for her to ward, she actually has to depend on a tanky jungler or top lane to bushcheck first.
5. She has to duo with a poke heavy adc.
6. She has to permanently stay backline and she can still get melted by assassins.

under this conditions she's only a strong pick if the enemy team doesn't pick any gap closing burst assassins or strong ganking jungler which is impossible unless the enemy team picks jungle shyvana and orianna mid. If she was innately tankier like Janna she'd be a better pick or if she did more damage or early cc she would go midlane as a utility support like lulu. Essentially Lulu does everything Sona does but better and is less liable in lane.

I think she's not as lane-dominant as she was before. Squishy poke/sustain - based champions kinda have to win lane in order to be relevant, else they will be outscaled by higher CC supports ({{champion:12}} {{champion:111}} {{champion:412}} ) that can offer more peel.

Sona still has her ult, but she kinda needs to dominate lane to be viable. And since she's a support I don't really see how she could get enough AP to make her damages/heal relevant. Unless you put higher scaling values / %health heal/shield?

Also, I've seen threads about how unrewarding it feels to put points in E. Sure, you max it last, but still, 1% per rank which is all what leveling this spell does, is really low.

It's a little bit of all of what you said.  The nerf she got not only handicapped her damage in a lot of ways, a base bonus to your allies AD/AP tends to go a lot further in most cases then a one time per cast buff of some magic damage.  This shows up super clearly in how she use to be great for tower pushes with giving herself and her allies a bonus 8-20 AD/AP.  Her current bonus only triggers off units, meaning that even if you are spamming skill the only bonus damage you will be adding is off your passive.  Where before her rework a sheen did a lot to help her damage output, but it wasn't a 100% core item if you wanted to do damage.  Her current style does not just suggest her building a sheen it outright requires before you can start doing even remotely reasonable damage.  However even with a spellblade effect she still suffers from having all her spells base cooldowns raised by a couple seconds each.

With her rework she lost a metric ton of what she brought to the table for a team.  The ability to chain together bonus damage and bonus resistances, made her a huge assist to your team and her value didn't sharply drop off after she used her ultimate.  However the thing the she brought most to a team was her ability to stay out of combat and still effect the flow of it.  You could stand 800-1000 range back and your presence was still felt.  To compensate for that she was made very physically weak so that if you did catch her she went down pretty fast.  Now she has to be much more aggressive and in the middle of combat to have any effect on the flow of combat.  She however was not given anything in the rework to make that easier.  So basically you have the same basic play style but now you have to be within about 300 range of your allies to be useful.


She is also getting crowded out by many of the other supports.  You have champions like Nami who are very similar to Sona but with better numbers, or having passives that function the same as Sona's abilities.  You also have champions like Annie or Morgana  who are powerful mid lane choices, but can also easily fill a support role without sacrificing all that much utility.  Add to this you champions like Naut who have great engages, decent damage, and are tanks allowing them to shrug off most damage you can throw at them.  However i would say the biggest offender is {{champion:223}}, here we have a champion who is not only built to be tanky and thus hard to push out of lane.  But also affords some reasonable utility in his slow and ability to gobble up allies to save them.  The cherry on top though is that even with all that power he is also afforded very good damage on his offensive skills.  


How is Sona support to compete when there are champions who are in most regards just better versions of her?  Champions who can go from their intended role to being support without sacrificing much to do so?  And with a meta that strongly favors tanky supports over damage/utility ones?

I would also like it remembered that most champions who are currently picked for support are more then capable of filling out more then just the support role.  However with the rework Sona lost her ability to be viable in the mid lane, and got relegated to being JUST a support.

I remember QQ threads from 2-3 years ago about her getting nerfs every patch because Rito no like invisible power or sustain bots.  I guess the QQers were right.  Seriously, if you nerf the invisible power and the sustain, that leaves what, her ultimate and her passive?

I don't know why she's dead in the LCS but doing ok on lolking.net numbers, though.  All I can think of is that mains are better at using {{item:3303}} than their enemies are at countering it.  I find Madame Qweqwe horribly boring to play regardless, though.

It's not the nerfs or the rework that pushed Sona out of competitive.  It's the meta that did.

Right now, the professional LoL meta for supports is to have as much reliable crowd control and to not die while roaming around the map.  Sona really doesn't do that well, as her auras are most effective with a partner.

Annie has three spells that proc her passive when it's ready.  When caught, she can stun her attackers and possibly get away.
Nautilus is the king of CC.
Alistar has his Headbutt/Pulverize combo.
Braum has his shield and his ultimate.
Thresh will always see competitive play, even if his spells did no damage whatsoever.

What Sona has is a thin skillshot ultimate as her CC, and probably needs to Flash to make it effective.
